image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: The ACCC alleges Qantas kept advertising and selling tickets for thousands of flights that had already been cancelled.

title.children: Qantas sold thousands of tickets to cancelled flights, ACCC alleges in new court action

image.altText: Jim Chalmers speaks at a press conference

items.synopsis: The competition watchdog has launched legal action against Qantas for allegedly selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled, while the ASX has opened flat. Follow live.

title.children: Treasurer says allegations Qantas sold tickets for cancelled flights 'deeply concerning', ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday we saw inflation in July fall to 4.9% — the lowest the Consumer Price Index has been in 17 months. That figure is likely music to the RBA's ears, who will meet to decide its next move on interest rates next Tuesday. But NAB this morning has released a note saying although inflation is coming down, price pressures are still likely to remain in the weeks ahead. That's because the monthly reading was goods heavy, while electricity prices rose by 15.7% because of rebates introduced in July, NAB market analyst Rodrigo Catril said. "Overall, the decline in the headline reading is welcome news for the RBA, but we are mindful tha t bigger price pressures are likely in August and September ," he said. "For one, these readings will be more services heavy and two, the energy/electricity jump is still working its way through. "Then one further known unknown is the impact from wage increases on services inflation, thus we remain wary of higher inflation prints over coming months .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation might be easing, but NAB warns price pressures will remain in the coming months

children.content: Yesterday we saw inflation in July fall to 4.9% — the lowest the Consumer Price Index has been in 17 months.
That figure is likely music to the RBA's ears, who will meet to decide its next move on interest rates next Tuesday.
But NAB this morning has released a note saying although inflation is coming down, price pressures are still likely to remain in the weeks ahead.
That's because the monthly reading was goods heavy, while electricity prices rose by 15.7% because of rebates introduced in July, NAB market analyst Rodrigo Catril said.
"Overall, the decline in the headline reading is welcome news for the RBA, but we are mindful tha
t bigger price pressures are likely in August and September
," he said.
"For one, these readings will be more services heavy and two, the energy/electricity jump is still working its way through.
"Then one further known unknown is the impact from wage increases on services inflation, thus
we remain wary of higher inflation prints over coming months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An update on Qantas' controversial travel credit scheme. The airline will remove the expiry date on COVID travel credits (that were due to run out at the end of this year). Around $2 billion worth of COVID credits were issued when borders closed in March 2020 and flights were grounded. In June, Qantas said around $400 million in credits still had not been used. The changes mean Qantas travel credit customers can request a cash refund at any point and Jetstar credit can be used for travel indefinitely. In a video message to customers, CEO Alan Joyce said he knows the credit system was not as smooth as it should have been. "While we've improved it recently, and extended the expiry date several times, people lost faith in the process. We hope this helps change that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas to scrap expiry dates on COVID travel credits

children.content: An update on Qantas' controversial travel credit scheme.
The airline will remove the expiry date on COVID travel credits (that were due to run out at the end of this year).
Around $2 billion worth of COVID credits were issued when borders closed in March 2020 and flights were grounded.
In June, Qantas said around $400 million in credits still had not been used.
The changes mean Qantas travel credit customers can request a cash refund at any point and Jetstar credit can be used for travel indefinitely.
In a video message to customers, CEO Alan Joyce said he knows the credit system was not as smooth as it should have been.
"While we've improved it recently, and extended the expiry date several times, people lost faith in the process. We hope this helps change that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello there. I'm Emily Stewart and I'll be taking you through all the financial news this afternoon! FYI - the Australian share market is still pretty flat at the middle of the trading day. The benchmark ASX 200 index was up a tiny 0.02% to 7298 points at 12pm AEST. The broader All Ordinaries was up 0.1% to 7514 points. (For live figures at any time, head to the start of the blog and open the post at the very top.) The energy sector continues to drag, down 2.5%, with consumer non-cyclicals also down 1.4%. Financials are up 0.7% and utilities up 0.5%. The top movers are: Lake Resources +4.6% IGO +4.5% Link Administration +4.4% Syrah Resources +3.6% Domain Holdings +3.1% The bottom movers are: Whitehaven Coal -9.1% Healius -7% Sayona Mining -6% Webjet -5.6% Chalice Mining -4.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still flat at lunch

image.altText: meat in a shop

items.synopsis: Prices paid to farmers for their lamb have fallen dramatically and shoppers should see prices decrease soon, according to the WA meat industry.

title.children: Cheaper meat on the horizon, but alarm for farmers as prices slump

image.altText: An e-scooter on its side on fire on a road in Marble Bar

items.synopsis: Firefighters say children were riding an e-scooter when it "combusted without warning". They say parts of the popular vehicles can pose significant fire risk.

title.children: 'Jostled' battery, heat blamed as e-scooter combusts with children on board

image.altText: Jacob smiles as he places his arm around his wife

items.synopsis: The head of WA's Corruption and Crime Commission tells a parliamentary committee it was unfortunate to see police drop hundreds of charges against Jacob Anthonisz, the alleged accomplice of a public servant who defrauded taxpayers of $22 million.

title.children: Authorities 'failed in their duty' before charges dropped in massive fraud case, corruption boss tells parliament

image.altText: Anthony Albanese with his hands up.

items.synopsis: With South Australia and Tasmania considered the key states in contest in the Voice to Parliament referendum, the prime minister hits Hobart after his visit to SA yesterday to announce the date of the referendum.

title.children: 'Convinced Tasmanians will vote Yes': Albanese spruiks Voice in Hobart on first full campaign day

image.altText: Man in drill shirt and broad-brimmed hat with background of red dirt and blue sky.

items.synopsis: More than half the bushfires in the Kimberley are deliberately lit, with residents worrying that arson has become the new norm.

title.children: A deliberately-lit fire has burned 17,000 hectares of bush on Chris's station — he and authorities are exhausted

image.altText: A man with a moustache in front of a party tent.

items.synopsis: The Queensland Supreme Court heard Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden lived at home in what was a "dysfunctional, toxic relationship".

title.children: Gold Coast councillor charged with murdering his stepfather released on bail after urgent hearing

image.altText: Gloved hands hold a selection of vapes above a bin of multi-coloured objects.

items.synopsis: A state school on Queensland's Gold Coast turns away from its hardline stance on vaping, in favour of an educational approach that's now being shared with other schools.

title.children: This school abandoned automatic suspensions for vaping. Here's what happened

items.synopsis: Born out of anti-government rallies during the pandemic, authorities say Germany's Reichsbürger movement is a growing threat. And it's forging ties with one of the country's biggest political parties.

title.children: Peter Fitzek says Germany doesn't exist. So he declared himself the king of a new 'kingdom'

image.altText: A semi-trailer and a wrecked car covered with a tarpaulin on the side of a country road.

items.synopsis: Police say a B-double truck travelling north on the Hume collided with a car that was turning onto the freeway, killing all four people inside. The truck driver, 30, was taken to hospital with non life-threatening injuries.

title.children: Four dead after truck, car collide on Hume Freeway in north-east Victoria

image.altText: A woman wearing a purple hoodie with her hair tied back walking with three other women

items.synopsis: A mother of six who fatally stabbed her partner in the thigh had endured violence in a "seriously dangerous" relationship that was "going to end in tragedy", a court has heard.

title.children: Relationship 'plagued by alcohol abuse, violence' ends in mum stabbing partner to death

image.altText: Busy area on Brisbane map in Uber app, shown with riddish shading and red lightning icons

items.synopsis: The workplace minister says a small increase to the cost of pizza deliveries is "a small price to pay" to ensure gig workers are safe, as the government unveils its plan for minimum rates of pay for workers earning income through apps such as Uber and DoorDash.

title.children: 'Small price to pay': Government reveals plans for minimum pay rates for gig workers

image.altText: glass of wine.

items.synopsis: It would be fair to expect wine to be vegan given it's mostly fruit, but the majority of drops are not. WA winemaker Alexi Christides says it comes down to how impurities are removed.

title.children: More winemakers opting out of animal-based purifiers to meet small but growing vegan market

image.altText: An orange moon appears behind a tower.

items.synopsis: Here are some photographs of the "blue" supermoon from around the world.

title.children: In pictures: Rare 'blue' supermoon brightens up night sky around the world

image.altText: military vehicles are queued in a row with palm trees behind them

items.synopsis: The ADF says soldiers from the Australian Army and the Timor Leste Defence Force have been taken to Royal Darwin Hospital for treatment following the crash.

title.children: ADF Bushmaster rolls near Darwin, injuring seven Australian, East Timorese troops

image.altText: A close-up of a mosquito on someone's skin.

items.synopsis: Health authorities are urging residents and travellers to cover up, wear long, loose-fitting and light-coloured clothing, and apply mosquito repellent.

title.children: Health warning as the Ross River virus detected in South West WA's mosquito population

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane is visible through a window at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: The assistant treasurer says it's "entirely uncontroversial" to say that Qantas must remain profitable, as the government weathers criticism over a decision to block Qatar from adding more flights, potentially reducing airfares.

title.children: Minister walks back comments that government intervened to protect Qantas' profits

image.altText: A woman leans against a tree with a Redfern sign behind her.

items.synopsis: While Yes voters in Redfern are hoping against heartache, the No campaign is targeting the undecided in Western Sydney.

title.children: How 'the Black capital of Australia' will be voting in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Anthony Albanese standing in front of "VOTE YES" branding as he announces the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Whichever way the referendum goes, there will be enormous ramifications for reconciliation and Indigenous advancement. There will be political consequences felt all the way to the next election — and the next six weeks absolutely matter, writes David Speers.

title.children: The differences between a referendum and an election help explain why the Voice's Yes camp is so confident

image.altText: An AFL player wearing a blazer smiles as he stands on stage alongside teammates during a presentation.

items.synopsis: For many years, GWS star Toby Greene played the role of the villain — now he is the skipper of the All-Australian Team. Andrew McGarry looks at his career arc, and the steps taken on the way to Greene's big honour.

title.children: From villain to captain — Toby Greene's career arc from AFL bad boy to All-Australian skipper

image.altText: A smiling Marissa Ballard holds up dog Louis in a portrait taken outside in a park setting

items.synopsis: From people who recently lost pets and aren't ready for another, to dog owners who want their pooch to have some company while they're at work, Australians are meeting online to share their animals.

title.children: Sharing pets a 'win-win' for dogs, their owners and the people who 'borrow' them

image.altText: People marching through a street carrying green, yellow, and blue flags

items.synopsis: Several nations have condemned a military junta in oil-rich Gabon as residents celebrate the end of a family dynasty.

title.children: 'Unconstitutional' Gabon coup draws widespread international condemnation

image.altText: A beekeeper and a woman in a tshirt scoop bees off the front of a car.

items.synopsis: A truck carrying five million bees crashes on a roadway in Ontario, Canada.

title.children: Canadian drivers urged to close car windows after millions of bees escape from truck

image.altText: A woman with brown hair holding a drink.

items.synopsis: Human remains which were found beside a busy highway in Goulburn have been identified as a Sydney woman who was murdered by her former boyfriend.

title.children: Human remains found by busy highway confirmed to be those of murdered Sydney woman

image.altText: Jaymz Lester-Stevens is lying in a hospital bed, with a blue hospital gown with hands up. Medical equipment all around.

items.synopsis: Bowel cancer affects more than 15,000 Australians every year, but a rise in cases among people below the age of 50 has specialists reiterating the warning signs.

title.children: Jaymz, 26, thought he was losing weight, until a bowel cancer diagnosis changed his reality

image.altText: An Australian female pole vaulter pumps her fist after winning an event in Switzerland.

items.synopsis: As commuters in Zürich's central railway station cheered her on, Australia's Nina Kennedy continues her outstanding form with victory in the Diamond League meet, a week after sharing the gold medal at the world titles.

title.children: World champion Kennedy sets national pole vault record in Swiss train station

image.altText: A small white fluffy glider with prominent ears, wide eyes and a little button nose peeks out of hole in a tree at night

items.synopsis: The EPA has issued a stop-work order for timber harvesting in Tallaganda State Forest following the discovery of a deceased endangered glider.

title.children: Logging operations halted in NSW forest after dead glider discovered

image.altText: A woman standing in a vacant lot

items.synopsis: Multiple Victorian home owners have made complaints to the state's building authority over allegedly defective works they say have left them hundreds of thousands of dollars out of pocket.

title.children: Andrea thought she was building the home she'd retire in. $1 million later, she and her family are in a 'nightmare'

image.altText: A group of four people dressed in white PPE and wearing red vests stand around an unmarked grave.

items.synopsis: Sudan's body retrievers pick through debris in a war zone to find the bodies of those killed in the country’s months-long civil war. The task is filled with hazards and could be deadly.

title.children: Stray bullets, falling debris and the risk of infection: The deadly task to bury Sudan's dead

image.altText: A man wearing a wet purple tshirt stands in knee-deep water filled with tree branches in the street

items.synopsis: Video footage and photographs from the region around Idalia's landfall showed ocean waters washing over highways and neighbourhoods swamped by extensive flooding as residents inspected the damage.

title.children: 'All hell broke loose': Hurricane Idalia tore down houses and flooded neighbourhoods in Florida
